paragraph: Other dualists have taken the second option (Mills 1996, Lowe 2003): they claim that mental properties do, as a matter of fact, over- determine their effects; while the physical cause is there, so too is an additional mental cause. This would be a curious state of affairs, but it seems possible. Even though it gives us an inelegant world, and one The Exclusion Problem 75 where it doesn’t seem mentality is causally needed, perhaps there is room here to save our intuitions about mental causation. In recent years, a number of philosophers who reject the ­traditional physicalist picture of mental phenomena have sought to avoid the ex- clusion argument by turning away from traditional property dualism to something like Russellian monism (see Chapter 4.) On that view, mental properties—or proto-mental properties that are not ­themselves mental but contain the seeds of mentality—actually ground all of the physical properties in the world. In contrast to the traditional ­picture, on which mental properties do not emerge until you get to the level of brains, Russellian monists see the world as having a mental or ­proto-mental base which ultimately explains the physical phenomena. Though this requires the denial of completeness, the Russellian mon- ist will argue that they can do so in an empirically ­unobjectionable way. For a critical discussion of the Russellian strategy as a solution to the exclusion problem see Howell (2015), and for a response see Alter and Coleman (2021). question: What is Russellian monism, and how does it address the Exclusion Problem?
answer: Russellian monism is a view that sees the world as having a mental or proto-mental base that ultimately explains the physical phenomena. On this view, mental properties are not just emergent at the level of brains, but actually ground all of the physical properties in the world. This approach can be seen as a way to avoid the Exclusion Problem by positing that mental properties are fundamental to the world.
